Hello; new to the list, new to junit, and still fairly new to java (have 
had two terms of java in college). I've read several articles, 
tutorials, and faqs about junit, and I feel that I grasp what they're 
saying... the examples they use make sense. But, then I turn and look at 
some code I've written and I don't see how to write tests for it.

For example, I'm working on a system that will generate dynamic web 
pages. One of my classes is called Site and it simply holds the domain 
name of the site as a string and has a HashMap to hold references to 
Page objects using the path to the page as the key. It looks like this:

public class Site {
	private String domainName;
	private HashMap pages;
	
	public Site(String dn){
		domainName = dn;
		pages = new HashMap();
	}

	public String getDomainName() { return domainName; }

	public void setDomainName(String dn) { domainName = dn; }
	
	public void addPage(String path, Page p){
		pages.put(path, p);
	}
	
	public Document getPage(String path){
		Page p = (Page) pages.get(path);
		return p.makePage();
	}
}

(the "Document" returned by getPage is an XML document that will be 
printed to the servlet's output stream)

So, does this class need a junit test? It seems pretty straight 
forward... I've actually written a simple test program that makes a Site 
object and a Page object with some simple xhtml, puts the reference to 
the Page object into the Site object's HashMap and then invoke's the 
getPage method and prints the results to the console. It all works fine.

Should I redo this test program in junit? And what would I assert? That 
the Page object in Site's HashMap is the same one I put in? That seems 
mind-numbingly obvious. Or, maybe I just haven't done anything 
complicated enough yet? But then, a lot of stuff I've read says I should 
write the test cases first and then write the class... this, even though 
I've also read that I shouldn't bother writing asserts for simple 
methods... what if that's all the class has?

I'd really like to write test cases for everything I write, but at this 
point I don't see the use of writing them for the classes I have so far. 
Please set me straight.

Ben
